1021074485988941824.text:
At the market close, the developers make the decision of the share valued at the higher price and give the "winners" Decision Tokens. There's no penalty for the "losers" and everyone's loot is refunded.

Decision Tokens would earn perpetual dividends from game & DLC sales.

1021074205239009280.text:
It'd require the developers' consent. But effectively it'd be a futarchy. One example:

Two markets are opened: (1) Yes, and (2) No. These correspond to some development decision in the game.

Players use their loot to either buy shares of "Yes" or shares of "No."

1018933744021823489.text: If a video game with #trueownership presells content to fund development, then players could open prediction markets with their in-game loot prior to launch to help steer the direction of the game's design.

1013148344082948096.text:
Why should game developers want to build blockchain games? 

Decentralized games are ‘extensible’. This means they encourage other applications to be built using the components of that game.

The result is network effects and increases the value and longevity of the initial game.pic.twitter.com/nlbSNFAgbv

1024234183932096513.text: Dating advice, I mean...gaming advice from @TomBollich (ex @Zynga): "The feeling of fulfillment is the purpose of a game. The most fun game you can play is almost losing, but not."https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rs_7ZmJBXJE …

1023723817825263616.text:
7/ On the difficulty of creating successful games...

“Games are hard - you put your lifeblood in them and then realise no one likes them. We made Texas Hold ‘em, then had 20 failures. Then made @MafiaWarMobile, then had 60 failures before we came up with @Farmville” —@tombollich

1023723293197496320.text:
6/ How blockchain will help video games..

“Blockchain will help games get over the ‘cold start’ problem (ie. nobody playing the game, therefore nobody else wants to play it). Crypto systems reward early adopters so it’s a way for games to catch the flywheel faster”

—@tombollich

1023722958198468609.text:
5/ (Cont’d)

“Gaming will cause mass adoption in blockchain. There’s already lots of overlap between crypto and gaming people:
Virtual currencies <>  Virtual game assets 
 Mining for crypto <>  Grinding for gold
 Mining pools <>  Gaming pools” 
—@jeon303

1023721697013248000.text:
5/ How games will encourage widespread adoption of crypto...

“There are games with 400 million players. If they start integrating crypto, that’s 400 million people using it.” —@tombollich

1023721511725674496.text:
4/ About game economies:

“To have a commercially successful game, you need a good economy. To have a good economy, you need an aspirational loop. To have an effective aspirational loop, you need to know your target market very well.”

—@tombollich

1023721306334715904.text:
3/ On game design... (cont’d)

“When building a crypto game, think of a regular game. Do you ask someone to buy crypto before they’ve played the game? Nowadays games don’t ask users for money first. Put them in an aspirational mood first, then ask for money later.“ 

—@tombollich

1023721177464762368.text:
3/ On game design...

“NFT is just a format. What gives value is the environment for which it was structured.”

“By themselves, NFTs have no meaning. Game design creates the meaning.”

—@jeon303

1023721036787773446.text:
2/ On what they find most interesting...

 Programmable currencies to build in-game economies
 Moving assets between different VR worlds

1023720715403448320.text:
1/ Great panel at @nifty_hacks with the incumbents of the gaming industry.

Key takeaways from Tom Bollich @tombollich, co-founder @zynga and Jason Jeon @jeon303 of NHN Entertainment below pic.twitter.com/o3oJznfdYu

1022334116472152064.text:
“It all boils down to licenses” - the current state of the law on ownership of digital assets.
#NFTs @PerkinsCoieLLP @nifty_hackspic.twitter.com/hs1euZZ5nD

1022329033659305984.text:
Digital items are not valuable because of true ownership. They are valuable because of the context and story surrounding the item. First create something that people love to own. Then make true ownership a non-negotiable feature of it.
#NFTs #blockchaingames @nifty_hacks

1022323071145762816.text:
Jeremy Gardner @Disruptepreneur of @AugurProject and @blockchaincapit on blockchain games: “Start centralized, with a goal to be decentralized. It’s more important to have something that works and has users. If not, why decentralize?”
@nifty_hackspic.twitter.com/DrPH4Khpzd
